questions.text: Nottingham Histologic Score is done for which carcinoma:
questions.solution:
All types of invasive carcinoma of breast are graded using the Nottingham Histologic Score. Carcinoe formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic rate and the points added to divide carcinomas into grade I (well differ-entiated), grade II (moderately differentiated), and grade III (poorly differentiated) types.

mas are scored for tubul

questions.text: Sezary-Lutzner cells are seen in ?
questions.solution: The histologic hallmark of CTCL of the mycosis fungoides type is the presence of the Sezary-Lutzner cells, which characteristically form bandlike aggregates within the superficial dermis.

questions.text: Malignancy of the Breast is likely to be associated with:
questions.solution: Proliferative disease with atypia includes atypical ductal hyperplasia and atypical lobular hyperplasia. Atypical ductal hyperplasia is present in 5% to 17% of specimens from biopsies performed for calcifications and is found less frequently in specimens from biopsies for mammographic densities or palpable masses. They have 4.0 to 5.0 (13% to 17%) relative risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesions showed IgA deposition at the tips of dermal papillae. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The most probable diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
    • Urticaria and grouped vesicles.
    • Predominantly males, most often in the third and fourth decade
    • Association with intestinal celiac disease and responds to a gluten-free diet
    • The plaques and vesicles are extremely pruritic.
    • The antibodies cross-react with reticulin, a component of the anchoring fibrils that tether the epidermal basement membrane to the superficial dermis.
    • The resultant injury and inflammation produce a subepidermal blister.
    • Fibrin and neutrophils accumulate selectively at the tips of dermal papillae, forming small microabscesses
    • True subepidermal blister.
    • Direct immunofluorescence- Discontinuous, granular deposits of lgA that selectively localize in the tips of dermal papillae.

questions.text: Lobular carcinoma of breast can be identified on IHC by lack of expression of which marker in tumor cell:
questions.solution: Lobular carcinoma is the subtype with the clearest association of phenotype and genotype. Most cases show biallelic loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that encodes E-cadherin. Due to loss of E-cadherin, lobular carcinomas are discohesive and often fail to incite a desmoplastic response.

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow shows which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Dohle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum see in in neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic 'puddles'.

In sepsis or severe inflammatory disorders (Ex: Kawasaki disease), leukocytosis is often accompanied by morphologic changes in the neutrophils, such as toxic granulations, Dohle bodies, and cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions found in a plasma cell with excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin.

Pappenheimer bodies are abnormal basophilic granules of iron found inside red blood cells composed of ferritin aggregates, or mitochondria containing aggregated ferritin.

Heinz bodies are inclusion bodies in red blood cells composed of denatured haemoglobin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient, presented with history of abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is seen as shown below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumour ?
questions.solution:
• GI stromal tumor (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen,
  • Most common site -stomach
  • Cell of origin -Interstitial cells of Cajal, or pacemaker cells, of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.
  • Peak age -50-60 years
  • Carney triad - gastric GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma
  • Carney- Stratakis syndrome- Loss of SDH function - GIST and paraganglioma
  • Approximately 75% to 80% of all GISTs - Gain-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT
  • Approximately 8% of GISTs have mutations that activate a PDGFRA.
  • The prognosis correlates with tumor size, mitotic index, and location
  • Gastric GISTs less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine.
  • Histological types- Spindle cell and epithelioid cell types.
  • Positive stains - CD117 / c-kitCD34,DOG1, vimentin

questions.text: Paterson-Brown-Kelly or Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with all except?
questions.solution:
• Paterson-Brown-Kelly or Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with nonprogressive dysphagia.
  • Other components are webs in the upper esophagus accompanied by iron-deficiency anemia, glossitis, and cheilosis.
  • The main symptom of webs is nonprogressive dysphagia associated with incompletely chewed food.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with obesity, metabolic syndrome and renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain associated with localized hyperaemia and warmth involving ankles, heels and knees. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals seen under polarised light are as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals which are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent

Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate within and around joints.

Gout can be divided into primary and secondary forms

The inflammation in gout is triggered by precipitation of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals into the joints, which results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes

Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines,

IL-1 is proinflammatory and promotes accumulation of neutrophils and macrophages in the joint

The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are (1) acute arthritis,(2) chronic tophaceous arthritis, (3) tophi in various sites, and (4) gouty nephropathy

Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout- large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, and bursae, earlobes, fingertips or kidneys.

Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.

questions.text: Trousseau syndrome is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Migratory thrombophlebitis, known as Trousseau's syndrome, occurs in about 10% of patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
  • It is attributed to the elaboration of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumor or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs.
  • A large'saddle' pulmonary embolus may result in sudden severe dyspnea and demise of the patient. Smaller emboli, as in this case, may produce pulmonary infarctions with some dyspnea and chest pain.

questions.text: A child presents with features of diabetes insipidus, proptosis, and radiographic defects in skull bones. A bone biopsy reveals that the lesions consist of eosinophils and dendritic cells as seen below. Electron microscopy is likely to reveal
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows proliferating Langerhans cells with abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds and surrounding eosinophils. The most likely diagnosis is Langerhan cell histiocytosis. The triad of diabetes insipidus, proptosis, and radiographic defects in skull bones is called Hand-Schuller-Christian triad. An electron micrograph is likely to show rodlike Birbeck granules with characteristic periodicity and dilated terminal end.

  • The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • Birbeck granules are pentalaminar tubules, often with a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket-like appearance which contain the protein langerin.
  • In addition, the tumor cells also typically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a.

Birbeck granules in Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • Lamellated myeloid or zebra bodies are seen in Tay-Sachs disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, Fabry's disease, mucolipidoses and mucopolysaccharidoses and in zebra body myopathy.
  • Flocculent densities in mitochondria are seen in irreversible cell injury
  • Beta pleated sheet is seen in amyloidosis

questions.text: Reactivated TB is most commonly located near
questions.solution: • Secondary pulmonary tuberculosis classically involves the apex of the upper lobes of one or both lungs

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl Bandhini developed a 10 mm area ofinduration on the left forearm 72 hours after intradermal injection of 0.1 ml of purified protein derivative (PPD). Which of the following is most likely to be seen on the X-ray of this patient?
questions.solution: • Most Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections are asymptomatic and subclinical infections. Calcifications and cavitation are more frequent after re Infection or reactivation of tuberculosis infections in adults Lymphadenopathy or subpleural granuloma formation is more frequent in primary tuberculosis infections A diffuse reticulo-nodular pattern is suggestive of miliary tuberculosis

questions.text: Atypical pneumonia can be caused by the following microbial agents except?
questions.solution:
Klebsiella pneumonia presents as typical air space pneumonia with cough productive of purulent sputum.

Causes of atypical pneumonias

  • Mycoplasma
  • Chlamydia pneumonia
  • Viral infections (Influenza, RSV, Adenovirus)
  • Legionella
  • Coxiella burnetti
  • Pneumocystis carinii

Mycoplasma is the commonest cause of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: Nodular glomerulosclerosis is seen in:
questions.solution: Most specific histological lesion in diabetic nephropathy is Nodular glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelsteil -Wilson lesions.

questions.text: A patient with unconjugated bilirubinemia has increased excretion of urobilinogen in his urine. This can be seen in all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution: • Biliary cirrhosis is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Rest all the mentioned options cause uncon jugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: Which type of Renal cell carcinoma is commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome?
questions.solution: Chromophobe Renal cell carcinoma is most common variant associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.

questions.text: Glomerular basement membrane is predominantly composed of which type of collagen:
questions.solution: The GBM consists of collagen (mostly type IV), laminin, polyanionic proteoglycans (mostly heparan sulfate), fibronectin, entactin, and several other glycoproteins.

choices.text: It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

questions.text: True about insulinoma is:
questions.solution:
• B-cell tumors (insulinomas) are the most common of pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. Most of them are benign. It is characterized by hypoglycemic episodes when blood glucose is less than 50 mg/dL,
  • Plasma levels of insulin and C peptide are elevated

questions.text: All of the following features of nephrotic syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Nephrotic syndrome is caused by a derangement in glomerular capillary walls resulting in increased permeability to plasma proteins. The manifestations of the syndrome include:

  • Massive proteinuria, with the daily loss of 3.5 gm or more of protein (less in children).
  • Hypoalbuminemia, with plasma albumin levels less than 3 gm/dL.
  • Generalized edema.
  • Hyperlipidemia and lipiduria.
